slides.notes: Welcome the audience to the presentation. Introduce yourself and share the goal of the session: to provide a foundational understanding of TypeScript. Mention the target audience: developers with basic JavaScript knowledge. Spend 1-2 minutes setting the stage for the talk.

slides.title: What is TypeScript?
slides.content:
• A superset of JavaScript
  • Adds static typing to JavaScript
  • Developed by Microsoft in 2012
  • Compiles to plain JavaScript
slides.notes: Start with the basics: explain that TypeScript builds on JavaScript. Highlight static typing as its key feature—this helps catch errors early. Mention that it's widely adopted and backed by Microsoft. Spend about 2 minutes here.

slides.title: Why Use TypeScript?
slides.content:
• Improved developer productivity
  • Catch bugs early with type checking
  • Better tooling and autocompletion
  • Scales well for large codebases
slides.notes: Focus on the benefits of TypeScript that resonate with your audience. Discuss how static typing leads to fewer runtime errors and better collaboration in teams. Highlight modern IDE support for TypeScript, which makes development faster and more efficient. Ask the audience: 'Who here has struggled with a bug that could have been caught by TypeScript?'

slides.title: TypeScript in Action
slides.content:
// Define a type
interface User {
  name: string;
  age: number;
}

// Use the type
const welcomeUser = (user: User): string => {
  return `Welcome, ${user.name}, age ${user.age}!`;
}
slides.notes: Walk through the code step by step. First, explain what an interface is and how it defines the shape of an object. Then, show how the function uses the 'User' type, ensuring that 'name' is a string and 'age' is a number. Highlight how this helps catch errors during development. Spend around 3 minutes here.

slides.title: Key Takeaways
slides.content:
• TypeScript enhances JavaScript with static typing
  • It improves code quality and maintainability
  • Adopting TypeScript is simple and worth it!
  • Start small—convert one file at a time
slides.notes: Summarize the key points of the presentation. Reinforce the benefits of TypeScript and encourage the audience to try it out. Suggest starting with a small project or converting a single JavaScript file to TypeScript. End with a call to action: 'Give it a shot!' Spend 2 minutes wrapping up, and open the floor for questions if time allows.
